utterances: Everyone knows the goal ahead, and everyone's on the same page to let our egos go to the side.
So, the personality of this team is mainly pride and focus.
The other reason for Baylor's success is Brittney Griner.
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #1: Griner wraps around for dunk number three and the show goes on.

Only half a dozen women ever dunked in a college game before Griner started her decorated career in 2009, and the Houston native's 18 career dunks and counting are more than all six of those players combined.
Figuring out how to contain an imposing 6-foot-8-inch senior who dunks is Louisville head coach Jeff Walz's challenge.
We're going to try and keep her away from the basket if possible, because that's what she does so well.
If she misses, she normally gets her own miss back.
The Cardinals opened their 90-minute practice on the floor of the Chesapeake Energy Arena yesterday with shooting drills.
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #2: Beyond the three.
Let's go.
We're taking threes.
Walz and Louisville freshman forward Sara Hammond say perimeter shooting is one way to keep the game close.
We have Antonita Slaughter who's just shot the ball, you know, like crazy.
And she's a person we feel really confident in shooting the ball, and also her length and her defense and rebounding ability.
Walz has succeeded this season by disguising his defensive schemes.
They might be in a zone one minute, then with 10 seconds left on the shot clock, they'll switch to man coverage.
That's why they're very good.
Baylor head coach Kim Mulkey.
If you look at stats, they create a lot of steals, and I attribute that to what Jeff has them doing defensively.
(SOUNDBITE OF CHEERING)
During Baylor's practice Saturday afternoon, Mulkey emphasized that point during drills up and down the hardwood.
(SOUNDBITE OF BASKETBALLS BOUNCING)
The other star of Baylor's starting five, junior point guard Odyssey Sims, says they spent Saturday night trying to figure out Louisville's defensive adjustments.
This is a new team.
We don't know too much about them.
Coach does a great job of that.
I understand that we're going up against a great team.
Brittney Griner is set to graduate in May, and likely heads to a professional career in the WNBA.
She says her final NCAA tournament run feels a little different.
A little bit more emotional, I guess you could say, after every game, just knowing, you know, it's your last time at that spot, or, you know, your last time on the home court.
This time it's my last one.
The winner of the Louisville-Baylor matchup takes on the victor of tonight's other contest in the Oklahoma City regional, Tennessee against Oklahoma.
For NPR News, I'm Brian Hardzinski in Oklahoma City.
This is WEEKEND EDITION, from NPR News.
I'm Rachel Martin.
Voters are heading to the polls in Syria today, casting ballots on constitutional reforms the government hails as a major step forward.
But the opposition is calling for a boycott.
And activists in besieged cities, including Homs, say the reforms can't undo the damage caused by the government's bloody crackdown on dissent.
NPR's Peter Kenyon is following events from Beirut.

If you had asked Syrian pro-democracy activists a little over a year ago whether they thought President Bashar al-Assad's Baath Party would give up its legal monopoly on political power, and implement term limits for the president, they probably would have sighed and said someday, God willing.
Now, those reforms are likely to be approved - as well as others that on paper, present a new and improved Syria.
But the events of the past year have many both inside and outside the country saying that these changes, at this time, are too little and far too late to restore trust in the government.
Turnout should be fairly strong in Damascus, where Assad retains a base of support, and in some minority districts elsewhere in Syria.
(SOUNDBITE OF PROTEST)
Right.
And it was in progress.
And I trust anything that he has his mind set to.
One example Freeman points to, the draft version set emission targets for entire states instead of specific polluters, and that was a weakness critics could've exploited in court.
Now what EPA has done is put the regulatory burden directly on the power plants themselves to cut their pollution.
And that's just much more direct, and it aligns better with the Clean Air Act.
Freeman says the EPA's new regulations are ambitious.
She says get ready for a legal ground war, one that she predicts will last the next couple of years and end up in the Supreme Court.
A more immediate question is whether a judge will issue a stay, essentially put the regulations on hold while both sides duke it out in court.
Jeff Brady, NPR News.
The tale of the pilgrims has been part of American mythology for a long time.
Coming over on the Mayflower, setting up a colony nearly 400 years ago - that story has taken on new meaning lately among conservative Christians.
NPR's Tom Gjelten reports that evangelicals highlight the pilgrims determination to be guided by the Bible.
The pilgrim story is one of the most dramatic in U.S.
history, and it's irresistible for filmmakers.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""THE PILGRIMS"")
September 6, 1620, an aging 180-ton ship called the Mayflower weighed anchor off Plymouth, off the south coast of England and set out on her own across the North Atlantic.
The pilgrim tale is retold in a new PBS film released in time for this Thanksgiving holiday.
Viewers are reminded that much of what we know about the pilgrims comes from the written recollections of their most famous governor, William Bradford.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""THE PILGRIMS"")
It was winter.
And they that know the winters of that country know them to be sharp and harsh.
What could they see but a hideous, desolate wilderness full of wild beasts and wild men?
The pilgrims' perseverance in the face of great odds made them American heroes.
But it's the story of the pilgrims' deep faith that interests Christian activists.
They often highlight the Mayflower Compact, the document that set forth the pilgrims' political views.
They were religious separatists fleeing persecution.
And in that compact, they said they undertook their voyage for the glory of God and the advancement of the Christian faith.

David Barton, an evangelical prominent in conservative Republican circles, often cites that phrase in his speeches, arguing that secular historians downplay the Mayflower compact because they don't like what it says.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Do you know what the Mayflower Compact says?
It says those people came here to propagate the gospel of the Lord Jesus Christ.
That was their goal.
That's what they were going to pursue in America.
Now, the problem with that is we're talking about a government document here with a lot of evangelical language in it.
It's an example, Barton said in that speech, that shows that religious expression in America's earliest days was not kept out of public life like it is today.
For evangelical conservatives, that's an important point in the debate over what religious practices should be allowed in the public arena these days.
In an interview with NPR, Barton said the pilgrims' story makes clear America was founded as a Bible-based, Christian nation.
They gave us private property out of the Bible.
They gave us civil rights out of the Bible.
They gave us elected government out of the Bible.
You'd have to say, you know, a lot of this was shaped by biblical principles.
And that's why the court said we're a Christian nation.
He's referring to an 1892 Supreme Court opinion.

But John Fea, a specialist in early American religious history at Messiah College, is wary of using the pilgrims' story to argue that America originated as a Christian nation or even that the founders of the nation were inspired by the Bible in writing the Constitution.
There's a lot of arguments out there that say, well, this was just in the air, right?
The Bible would have influenced their construction of this even though it's never mentioned.
You know, for me as a historian, I need a smoking gun.
Maybe they just left it out because they deliberately wanted to leave it out, and there were conscious efforts to do so.
Ric Burns, who wrote and directed the new PBS film, says his goal was to lay out the genuine pilgrim story.
Our aim is just to say, hey, what really happened?
What made the old world intolerable to these people who came over?
What did they believe?
What happened to them along the way?
And let me tell you, this is more like Joseph Conrad's ""Heart Of Darkness"" in many ways than it is, like, let's all sit down for turkey for Thanksgiving.
Indeed, Burns punctures some myths.
The pilgrims made peace with some of the Indians they encountered, but they slaughtered others.
They were devout, but they weren't exactly proponents of religious freedom.
People who didn't accept their strict beliefs were expelled from their community.
In some ways, they weren't good early-American models.
But American history is full of contradictions.
The pilgrim experience is one part of our national origin, along with all the other stories that make up our heritage.
Tom Gjelten, NPR News.
Good morning, I'm Linda Wertheimer.
The fastest-growing city in the country is not what you'd expect, not a trendy tech hub, not an edgy edge city.
It's The Villages, in Central Florida.
Nobody under 55 can live there.
Aging boomers have made The Villages the biggest retirement community in the world - specializing in microbrew, golf courses and November-December romance; also, the world's longest golf cart parade.
